ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Mathematical proofs, as well as counting and combinatorics, graphs, trees
Proof writing
A good introduction to topics in proof writing, graph theory and combinatorics.
None. I honestly couldn't tell you anything I learned.
Mathematical analysis of graphs, combinatorics, and general proof-writing skills
Combinatorics and graph theory
You learn about graph theory, counting, induction, and other mathematical techniques.
combinatorics, graph theory
Bunch of combinatorics and graph theory stuff

Broadly, I learned combinatorics and graph theory. New to me, I learned proof methods associated with discrete math, such as counting the same quantity in two different ways, as well as combinatorial proofs for algebraic facts. I enjoyed seeing the connections of graph theory to group theory, data analysis, and physics.
I enjoyed learning a lot of math that I hadn't seen before, and appreciated the opportunity to improve my proof writing abilities.
Combinatorics and graph theory
combinatorics and graph theory

Due to my math competition experience, I did feel that a lot of the skills in this course were building on what I already had rather than wholly new. That said, I felt that this course enhanced my spatial intuition for mathematics, helped build additional comfort with discrete problem solving, and refreshed and expanded my combinatorics knowledge.
Course material changes year to year. Second half was a lot of graph theory, first half was a lot more varied.
I learned about different proof techniques.
Basic concepts in Discrete Mathgraphs, combinatorics, function estimation.
All about discrete math--combinatorics, graph theory, etc
Discrete Mathematics
Doing psets, mostly.
Topics in combinatorics and graph theory

Topics covered in the class were counting/combinatorics, estimation, and graphs. Learned critical theorems, algorithms, and strategies for each of these.

Practice with proof-writing.
I learned combinatorics and graph theory through a proof based class.
Combinatorics: basic counting then lots of graph theory. Would be good stuff for all aspiring math or CS majors

Learned the most about combinatorics, principle of inclusion-exclusion, relations, graphs, trees, and their related algorithms. Coming in, I didn't too have proof-based math experience, so this course I'd say is great as a first proof-based math class with Professor Kenyon!
Matg

This course focused primarily on basic combinatorics and graph theory. Accordingly, my knowledge in both fields expanded from something negligible to a point where I feel like I actually understand and can apply the topics covered. 

As for skills, this course developed my proof-writing skills, especially under time pressure. It also developed my ability to reason with discrete (rather than continuous) structures.
I learned discrete
I learned more about combinatorics and graph theory. I practiced my proof-writing skills.
Learned various topics in combinatorics, graph theory, and counting.
Several introductory concepts in discrete math (combinatorics, equivalence relations, inclusion-exclusion, graph theory, trees, spanning trees, etc.)
Knowledge of basic combinatorics and graph theory. Knowledge of how to write proofs and mathematical thinking
I developed a foundation in discrete mathematics, learning about important fields in number theory, graph theory, and some linear algebra and discrete geometry.
Got more practice writing proofs, combinatorics, graph theory, trees
I got a good overview of the field of discrete math, and learned some cool more specific things as well.
discrete math

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The class started really slow, but by the end some amount of linear algebra and single variable calculus was essentially assumed, so be warned.

Also, expectations for p-sets are unclear.

The proof-based psets were a good level of difficulty and the breakout sessions during class were interesting. Sometimes it felt like the theorems were sort of random facts instead of being all tied together coherently

This course was pretty poorly organized and there weren't enough TAs/ULAs. The lecture were engaging though, but did not prepare you for the homeworks. there is very little available review material for any exam.
Lectures with prof. Kenyon were a ton of fun. I really enjoyed when we did breakout problem sessions. The workload and difficulty of homework/exams was perfect. A very good course overall.
The homework doesn't match up with the lectures in class well, so it's kind of hard to do homework.

Strengths: fairly interesting material, Professor Kenyon's lectures are clear and helpful, reasonable problem set length and difficulty 
Weaknesses: little support outside the classroom; I would recommend for the professor to actively post a reading schedule instead of having us guess what chapter we're doing, since most of the lectures are straight from the book anyways; more ULA/TF office hours would be helpful as the material gets difficult

I think that professor Kenyon was an engaging lecturer. However, I thought that the second half of the course material was pretty boring because it was just day after day of random theorems in graph theory. The class did not have a good flow and just felt like a hodge podge of material.

strengths: covered a wide range of materials. I had already knew a lot of the combinatorics coming from competition math, but I still was able to learn a lot  from the game theory sections

weaknesses: lectures seemed a bit unorganized at times, but were well structured overall
Kenyon is a good professor and reasonable with grading and workload

Strengths: Professor Kenyon is a very engaging lecturer, and I enjoyed the problem-solving sessions on Thursdays. The problem sets were very challenging, and the exams were fair given that they were timed and closed-book. We cover a fair amount of material, especially combinatorics and graph theory. Weaknesses: We didn't get much feedback, since most of the homeworks weren't graded until late in the semester. The class had widely varying backgrounds, which made it difficult for Professor Kenyon to pace the class and know what prerequisite material to review.

The teaching itself was very good, but I thought the textbook for the class was very confusing and resulting in a lack of understanding on my part in regards to the midterm and some of the problem sets.

The ULAs were extremely helpful. I am not exaggerating when I say that if it wasn't for Nhi and Christopher, I would not have made it through this course at all. MATH 244 is kind of like "Defense Against the Dark Arts" from Harry Potter in that the syllabus changes every semester and the professor changes less frequently. This was Professor Kenyon's first semester teaching the class and while fun at times, I found the syllabus topics to be a little bit random. One day we would be learning combinatorics and then another day we would be pivoting to graph theory and then colorings. At the end of the semester, it was hard for me to wrap my head around what exactly discrete math is and its applications. It would also be very helpful if the lectures were recorded. And this class, like many others, had issues with the graders.
Strengths: Great lectures, very clear. Problem sets were doable and TAs/ULAs were very helpful.

Strength: the professor is so good at delivering his ideas clearly. The lectures are super engaging.
Weakness: the pset problems are quite hard. It takes me at least 6 hours a week to finish the problem set.

I think the TAs could have been a little clearer in their explanations. And I think sometimes its not worth spending all of class time on proofs that are too complex for HWs or exams.
I liked that the class was very didactic and very manageable. Overalll great class!

This course is quite strong when it comes to covering a breadth of material. I think it would be well served by having some sort of way to put players in touch with more advanced material--bonus problems, perhaps?
Strengths are that the textbook was an incredible source of information for the homework problems. Weaknesses are that everything in class could be learnt through a couple of pages in the textbook

With Professor Kenyon:
Strengths: Grading is very fair based on the breakdown and also, the workload and pacing is very reasonable for a college math course
Weaknesses: Discrete Math...
The lectures were engaging.
Prof. Kenyon is sweet but a terrible lecturer. He shows proofs that are wayyyyy to difficult for this pseudo introductory class. You learn from the textbook and online sources, not from class.

Strengths: really cool topics and problems, solid professor
Weaknesses: very slow grading
great professor. classes need more structure.

Strength: Covered a lot of material. Some problems are fun, especially the graph theory stuff. The TAs of this class are great.

Weakness: Many mistakes made by the grader. The solutions to psets contain mistakes, and are generally not helpful. Most of the combinatorics in this class are like math competitions, i.e. useless. I don't know why the heck we learn these counting tricks when I will forget everything immediately after final. Would recommend to make things more intuitive and visual, like the graphs.

problem sets were good
wish there was more in class problem solving
Relatively disorganized content but found it interesting, psets were extremely different from exams (much harder/more reliant on cleverness than application of concepts)

Good course. At times, topics close to linear algebra were discussed, even though linear algebra isn't a prereq. They weren't on the final though or any of the problem sets so it didn't have any impact other than being a bit confusing. Every week, we worked on problems in groups for a portion of one of the classes, which was nice. 

It was kenyon's first time teaching the class, so it was a bit disorganized at the beginning. Also problem sets took too long to get returned to us.
make tests harder so grade isn't dependent on minute details and more on whether students have problem solving skills

I thought that many of the proofs weren't graded as rigorously as they could've been but its nearly impossible to increase this standard because of the size of the class. However, this course definitely gives a good general baseline for mathematical intuition.

Strengths: Very well-designed course around a good textbook, content is fun and workload isn't too bad

Weaknesses: Work felt repetitive at times and some problems required such outside thinking that I could only do them in office hours (but such is the reality of discrete math).
Strength: Professor Kenyon is a terrific lecturer! In addition, the lectures followed the textbook very closely, which made it very easy to follow on and review concept at home.
Nixe

This course provides an excellent basis for a number of topics in discrete math, especially those which have applications in CS. This is the course's main strength--it surveys a wide field, and provides a challenging introduction to these CS topics.

It's fundamentally a proof-based math class, and applications are not always so obvious or well-explained. This might be a strength or a weakness, depending on your interest in pure math, but overall I'd say it's more favorable to pure mathematics than applied math.
Lectures should be recorded, homework grades should be completed sooner

It was the first time this professor taught this course, so it could have been more structured throughout. However, he did a good job explaining concepts, and an even better job when he had more time to prepare for the class. Side note: I thought the textbook was excellent. Worth reading and processing.
Great lectures. Reasonable psets. Would probably prefer a slightly faster pace. Grading was pretty slow.

Professor Kenyon was a great lecturer and kind professor. I also found the peer tutors and TA to be very helpful with homework. Sometimes the homework felt too difficult for a student without a background in proof-based math, which was not a prerequisite for the course.

Pretty well taught all around. The nature of the course is hard to compare year to year since the topic is so broad. I enjoyed it as is. The graph theory section of the course got very involved with proofs that we never used in any application which could be cleaned up.
The homework problems challenging but helpful in understanding the content, though the lecture could be a bit more engaging.

I thought the lectures were plenty interesting, and I really appreciated the breakout sessions that we would often have at the end of class. The homework was helpful but somewhat inconsistent in length and difficulty which sometimes made it hard to plan.
nice professor

Strengths - course material was interesting; abundant amount of teaching fellows and office hours available to support student learning; workload was fair (weekly psets, one midterm, one final); exams were graded very quickly, which is much appreciated 

Weaknesses - problem sets were graded extremely late (over a month and a half late for most), which meant that we had little feedback on how we were doing prior to exams; lack of practice exams for the midterm and final, which made the content tested seem unpredictable

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're at all interested in computer science or other discrete theory, this course is essential.
Yes, it's a good more rigorous mathematical look at pretty useful and practical stuff and the workload is okay for a proof-based class
I would not recommend it unless it was required for a major.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially if professor Kenyon is teaching. Solving the problems was a lot of fun, and I felt like I have become a better problem solver as a result of it. I felt that the difficulty of the homework and exams was quite fair.
No, unless you absolutely need it, but just take it with a different professor.
Yes. It's a rigorous course that teaches you about combinatorics and graphs. It's not the most exciting class you'll take, and be prepared to spend ~10 hours on each problem set.
Yeah its a good intro course to discrete math

I think that it is a pretty easy math elective. You will learn some things, and the lectures are relatively interesting. The PSETs can be challenging at times, but the exams are very straightforward. Overall, it's a pretty decent math class.
Yes, this is definitely a course you have to take. The topics are decently accessible to all and are pretty important to understand math more as a whole.
Yes I'd say so, the professor for MATH 244 however always seems to change from semester to semester. If Kenyon teaches it again I'd recommend it

Yes, especially if Professor Kenyon is teaching it. It is an interesting class that covers an important area of math, critical to rounding out a mathematics education at Yale. While challenging, it is quite accessible, with the only prerequisites being basic calculus and linear algebra.
Yes, but after more math than Math 115. I think taking at least linear algebra before taking this course would be a good idea.
I would not. If they're trying to do an S&DS major, I would recommend finding another class to fulfill the requirement.

Yes! I enjoyed this course -- it was not too stressful and well-organized. Prof. Kenyon lectures very well and clearly, and was always willing to re-explain things and answer questions. As far as math classes go, this one is lighter than most others. We followed the textbook pretty closely. Problem sets were not too bad -- maybe 5-6 hours/week, and exams were easier than the problem sets.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes! Great class. Graphs are cool! and workload is very manageable
Yes. If they are interested in discrete mathematics in general, this is a perfectly good course which I would recommend they take over alternatives.
If you need to take a Discrete Math, take this class. If you are looking for a QR credit, there are other options.

Two reasons to take it: 1. If you need it for the major or 2. It's taught by Professor Kenyon and you're interested in discrete. For reason one, you're outta luck. For reason two, Kenyon is honestly great. His lectures go at a very reasonable pace that even a first year can understand and begin their Yale math career. If only I was more interesting in discrete math, this would've been a great math course.
I would recommend this course with Kenyon as the professor. He is a great lecturer, the psets are challenging & rewarding, & the exams are fair.
No. The lectures are unclear. Take only if you are required to do so.
Yes! Very cool area of math
If youre taking it for the requirement, then yes. Prof. Kenyon is a great lecturer, but this is a very broad introduction to topics in discrete math, so at times the class felt unfocused.
Don't take it if you don't have to. If you must, try to take it with a friend who is good at math competitions. If the teacher is a math Olympiad winner, run away as fast as you can.
yes, good basis for cs and math interested people
If you like competition type math

I'd recommend this course if you're interested in proofs, discrete math, or if you need to take it. It wasn't very interesting for me, but I don't like proofs, and I'm not going into CS so it's not super relevant to me. But that's a personal thingnot a bad class.
Yes, this is a very good class to first learn proofs in.

Yes, of course! This is an awesome class. If you've done math competitions before a lot of the class is going to be extremely gutty (at least in this version; I've heard bad things about when Cosmin teaches it), the amount depending on how much you've done. The first half of the class is a lot of combinatorial counting and the second half is mostly graph theory; I found the second half harder because I haven't done proof-based graph theory before. You are expected to do rigorous proof-writing but they don't provide any guidance so be wary of that. The grading also felt arbitrary at times, perhaps due to that fact - over the course of the semester, I got full credit for incomplete proofs but nitpicked on much more foolproof solutions (at least in my opinion). But Prof. Kenyon is great and it was a very worthwhile class to take. Would highly recommend to all CS and math majors regardless of experience.
YES! This was only my second proof-based math class (after math 225), and the difficulty of the class felt perfect.
Yes

I would recommend this course primarily to math majors, especially those with an interest in computer science, and particularly motivated CS students. It is a proof-based math class, and the applications are secondary. This is variously a strength and a weakness, depending almost entirely on your interest in abstraction.

It was a lot of work, but it was rewarding work, and I feel like I learned a lot. It's not an easy class, but if you're interested in and decent at proof-based math, it won't kill you.
I think the course was pretty good for those interested in the subject, but the textbook was not good and grading was not easy

Sort of. I think the content was extremely interesting, and some of the proofs were downright beautiful. However, I think it could have been better organized and taught, and I feel like it would have been nice to get more detailed feedback on our work at more points in the semester so we could learn better. The problem sets tended to be interesting, but I feel like we didn't have many other opportunities to show what we knew. If you think the math is cool, you should consider taking the class, but don't expect a stand-out amazing class experience. The professor was a nice guy but I wish he was more available.
Would definitely recommend to any math or cs major due Important topics and the different and interest type of math covered.
Yes, the topics were interesting.
Its a niche area of math, but helpful in building mathematical thinking as an intro course. Take it if you need it for future courses or to fulfill a requirement its a great option.

This course is ideal if you are interested in higher level proof-based mathematics, or if you want to do computer science and wish to have a strong grasp of concepts related to algorithms and computational complexity.
Yes. The PSETS were pretty interesting
Yes! This is a very interesting course if you are interested in math, and it explores a lot of cool things outside the traditional introductory math sequence.
good course, informative

The course is interesting, but it is also challenging. With the way it is currently structured, with psets being graded late and the lack of practice exams for the midterm and final, there is little way for students to get feedback on how they're doing (though to be fair, the psets being graded late is out of the professor's control and is on the graders). However, as such, I would recommend this course only if the student has a strong math background already (ideally in competition math) or if they were extremely motivated and can dedicate a lot of time towards doing well in this class.
